sub_title: Clinical Data Scientist | Neuroscientist | Science Communicator
summary:
I began my scientific journey by studying the building blocks of organic material for drug discovery. I then specialized in neuroscience and cognition and made an effort to find the links between cell biology, physiology and behaviour. In the last few years, I focused on developing computational models to explain and predict experimental findings.

I am now keen to apply my research experience to real-world problems and explore novel roles in the fields of life science and healthcare. I am looking for opportunities that allow me to make a more direct and measurable contribution to society and step beyond basic research.

• A driven, adaptable and proactive neuroscientist with the desire to learn who thrives in a fast-paced and deadline-driven environment. Has the ability to handle several projects in multidisciplinary and multinational teams. More than 10 years of hands-on research and programming experience resulting in 12 scientific publications.
• Hard-working perfectionist with exceptional attention to detail. Effective project management demonstrated by the completion of my MSc and PhD, and the opportunity to undertake collaborative projects outside of the scope of my PhD.
• Excellent communication skills with the ability to understand, interpret, and communicate complex scientific information and data. Presented work at more than 15 national and international conferences, organised 5 public engagement events directed at patient groups and high school students, and created 5 educational training videos for an online platform.

Neuronal Signalling in the Nervous System

profile_positions.description:
As a clinical data scientist, I contribute to the development of a sustainable European Registry for Rare Cancers (EURACAN), with a particular focus on sarcomas. Sarcoma is a heterogeneous group of rare cancers of connective tissue that are frequently misdiagnosed (30-40%). Due to the rarity of such cancers (6 in 100.000 people), data is limited. By combining data from multiple cancer registries across Europe, we can gain new insights into this disease. 

I am the Data & Tech work package lead of the Blueberry project. We first convert data to a standardized data model, such as the Observational Medical Outcome Partnership - Common Data Model (OMOP-CDM),  and then implement a federated learning network, to ensure that data are Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable (FAIR)

I also generate new clinical insights for sarcomas using the federated EURACAN registry.
profile_positions.title: Clinical Data Scientist

profile_positions.description: I am an editor of the special research collection in Frontiers Neuroinformatics "Navigating the Landscape of FAIR Data Sharing and Reuse: Repositories, Standards, and Resources"
profile_positions.title: Guest Associate Editor

profile_positions.description:
As a neuroinformatics researcher and data curator for the EBRAINS Research Infrastucture (developed by the Human Brain Project), I am responsible for the development of research-driven ontologies, use-cases, optimisation of curation workflows, and the management and ingestion of data and metadata into a Knowledge Graph. Co-developer of the openMINDS metadata model (https://github.com/HumanBrainProject/openMINDS).

I am also actively involved in the communication, branding, and dissemination of new insights and services offered by EBRAINS, including community building and the development of training material (INCF Training Space). Created the monthly twitter series #DebunkingDataSharingMyths to demystify misconceptions about data sharing.

I work closely with an international team of developers and curators to further develop the EBRAINS infrastructure for FAIR (Findable, Interoperable, Accessible, Reusable) data sharing (www.ebrains.eu).
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral researcher in Neuroinformatics and data curator EBRAINS

profile_positions.description: As a computational neuroscientist, I analysed and identified trends in complex data. Based on these results, I implemented reinforcement learning (machine learning) models, and documented the findings in written reports.
profile_positions.title: Post Doc Computational Neuroscience

profile_positions.description:
Thesis title: Physiological modulation of learning and decision-making

In my PhD, I developed a theoretical, biologically relevant framework to probe the influence of physiological signals on brain function (published in the Journal of Computational Biology). The computational simulations provided quantitative predictions that I tested in computerised decision-making tasks in human volunteers. I successfully implemented reinforcement learning models and statistical analyses (e.g. regression) to analyse and identify trends in complex data. I have written a further two manuscripts on my PhD project, published in Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience and Brain & Behavior. 

My effective project management skills allowed me to collaborate on projects outside the scope of the PhD. In one project we tested the effects of an anticholinergic drug (used for Parkinson's disease) on learning, memory and reward processing in human volunteers. Brain activity during these tasks was measured with EEG and eye tracking). This paper is currently under review. For another project, I was asked to provide my computational expertise and model experimental data. This project is published in Nature Scientific Reports.
profile_positions.title: Doctoral Researcher

company.name: The Researcher Strategy Consultancy, University of Oxford

profile_positions.company: The Researcher Strategy Consultancy, University of Oxford
profile_positions.description: In a multidisciplinary team of 6 people, we developed a market access and reimbursement strategy for a local start-up aiming to bring a medical device to the market in the United States. I was the primary client contact for this team and was responsible for communicating with the client in written and verbal form to ensure that the team met the required objectives in a timely manner.
profile_positions.title: Client Liaison - Strategy consultant

profile_positions.description:
I investigated the mechanisms underlying cellular, synaptic and circuit function in the basal ganglia that control motor actions and are impaired in Parkinson's Disease. For this project, I used a various techniques, including rodent behavioural tasks; in vitro whole cell patch clamp recording; stereotaxic surgery and intra-cranial viral application in rodents; optogenetics; immunohistochemistry; and fluorescence/ confocal microscopy.

In addition to my primary project, I organised and led bi-weekly journal club meetings for up to 10 people and co-supervised visiting MSc students.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate

company.name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

profile_positions.company: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
profile_positions.description:
In this internship, I Investigated neural circuitries that are involved in eating behaviour. This research is published in peer-reviewed scientific journal (Journal of Neuroscience).

Supervisors: AM Stamatakis and GD Stuber
profile_positions.title: Research Intern

profile_positions.description:
For this project, I performed a systematic literature review of the role of the appetite-stimulating hormone leptin in the regulation of energy balance and body weight. This work is published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal (Journal of Chemical Neuroanatomy)

Supervisor: G van der Plasse and RAH Adan
profile_positions.title: Research Intern Translation Neuroscience - Brain Center Rudolf Magnus

profile_positions.description:
In this research project, I investigated the motivational aspects of social play behaviour in young rats, whilst manipulating the level of dopamine, noradrenaline, opioids and cannabinoids. This research is published in 4 peer-reviewed scientific journals

Supervisors: EJM Achterberg and LJMJ Vanderschuren
profile_positions.title: Research Intern Translation Neuroscience - Brain Center Rudolf Magnus

profile_positions.description: As a teaching assistant, I supervised and assisted groups of up to 20 students with practical assignments. I also mentored 15 high school students with their graduation projects.
profile_positions.title: Teaching Assistant
